Caption: Waddle you know its #WorldPenguinDay!   There are 18 known species of penguins in the world today. Some call snowy Antarctica home while others live further north in relatively warmer climates. But they all share a similar dark and light coloration distinctive waddle and special adaptations for life in the ocean!   Learn more about penguins with the #linkinbio!  #PenguinDay #Penguins #Seabirds #Ocean #MarineLife

Caption: We re taking the Trump administration to court to protect our oceans from dirty offshore drilling! Oceana and our allies are suing the Trump administration challenging an order that revokes ocean protections and opens vast areas to offshore drilling. The lawsuit seeks to reinstate safeguards for millions of acres of ocean along the Atlantic Pacific Gulf and Alaska coasts emphasizing the need to protect ocean wildlife marine habitat and coastal communities This legal action marks a significant stand against policies that prioritize fossil fuel expansion over environmental conservation. President Trump does not have the authority to destroy our oceans in this way and Oceana is fighting to ensure he does not. Read more with our full press release. Link in bio. #ProtectOurCoast EarthJustice lcvoters defendersofwildlife sierraclub nrdc_org centerforbiodiv thenortherncenter Greenpeace keepalaskawild surfrider healthygulf turtleislandrestorationnetwork

Caption: You OTTER believe it - #SeaOtterAwarenessWeek is here!  Unlike many marine mammals the sea otter doesnt have blubber to keep warm. Instead it has super super thick fur - some of the densest in the whole animal kingdom! The sea otters coat has two layers which traps air against the otters skin keeping it warm dry and buoyant. But this fur can also pose major challenges for sea otters. These mammals were nearly hunted to extinction for their pelts until the turn of the 20th century. And while their populations have seen some recovery sea otters still face serious threats including oil pollution and habitat loss. Stand up for sea otters with a symbolic adoption today! All donations help power Oceana s campaigns to protect these incredible animals from the threat of dirty offshore drilling while also helping preserve the habitat they and so many other creatures call home. Link in bio.  : Shutterstock

Caption: Today the Trump administration issued layoffs to NOAA employees. These roles are essential to maintaining a healthy ocean in the United States. They keep fisheries healthy protect endangered animals like whales and turtles and support critical scientific research. Without them America s oceans Great Lakes and coastal economies will suffer severe consequences. NOAA is a critical tool for protecting our oceans and its up to us to defend it. Contact your U.S. representatives to tell them to push back & stand up for NOAA today. Link in bio.

Caption: The narwhal is so strikingly unique it almost seems like a mythical creature at times.  This excerpt from Katherine Rundell s new book  Vanishing Treasures: A Bestiary of Extraordinary Endangered Creatures  explores the extraordinary reality of the narwhal as well as the all-too-real threats it faces. Our oceans are full of fascinating and awe-inspiring creatures like the narwhal and it s up to us all to protect this wildlife and the waters they call home. Narrator: Lenny Henry

Caption: We stand in support with all those affected by the horrific floods in Spain. Over 140 people have been killed dozens are missing and towns and roads across southern and eastern regions of the country remain flooded. While heavy rains are common on the Spanish Mediterranean coast this time of year this is the heaviest rainfall in decades. Extreme weather events like this are becoming more and more common as our climate changes and global temperatures rise. We cannot ignore what s all-too clear: the climate crisis is here now and it s bringing devastation to people around the world. We must take immediate action to tackle the climate crisis including stopping dirty offshore drilling. Our entire future depends on it.   :   Gabriel Gallo / Greenpeace

Caption: Dont sleep on #WorldWalrusDay!Recognizable by their prominent tusks the walrus is one of the most iconic animals in the Arctic! These titanic tusks are actually specialized canine teeth.  Walruses use their tusks in a variety of ways including fighting with other walruses defending against potential predators or even digging into ice to help the walrus haul itself out of the water.Learn more about the wonderful #walrus with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Time to seal-abrate   its #SealDay!  There are 18 species of true seals also called earless seals around the world today. One additional species the Caribbean monk seal is considered extinct as it has not been sighted since 1952.Seals can be found in waters around the world from the Arctic to Antarctica. Their flippers and streamlined bodies make them perfectly suited to spend most of their life in the waters they call home! Learn more about seals with the #linkinbio. #InternationalDayOfTheSeal

Caption: ANOTHER TRAGEDY: A dead hawksbill sea turtle was found on a Florida beach this week. While its cause of death is undetermined the turtle had plastic both in its mouth and wound tightly around one of its front flipper. This sea turtle was found along the same beaches where a dwarf sperm whale calf washed ashore in September. The whale which did not survive had ingested a large plastic bag. Plastic pollution is injuring and killing far too many animals around the world. We need serious action to combat the plastic crisis and that involves reducing our production of single-use plastic at the source. Speak up to tackle plastic pollution and protect wildlife today with the #linkinbio. #BreakFreeFromPlastic   : Hawksbill photos credited to Oceana/Maggie Boselowitz/St. Johns County Habitat Conservation Team : Dwarf sperm whale photo credited to Oceana/Joseph Pellegrino & St. Johns County Office of Public Affairs.

Caption: North Atlantic right whale calf alert! First-time mom  Accordion  was spotted with her newborn off the coast of New York   an unusual location as most right whale calves are born further south in warmer waters. Scientists aren t sure why this pair is so far north but their journey comes with risks. Right now they re swimming dangerously close to busy shipping lanes and boat strikes are one of the main causes of death for these critically endangered whales. With under 370 right whales left every calf matters! Speak up for stronger protections for the #RightWhaleToSave today. Link in bio.  : Photo by NOAA/Northeast Fisheries Science Center under NOAA permit 27066

Caption: Happy #WorldWildlifeConservationDay!     All these magnificent species were spotted during Oceanas on-the-water expeditions over the years. These voyages around the world allow us to document unique ocean habitats learn about the wildlife that live there and to bring them to life for policymakers and the public. This enables Oceana to win policy victories that protect these special places.  Since our first expedition we have led over 60 scientific expeditions and conducted thousands of ocean surveys. These expeditions have been instrumental in Oceana protecting over 10 million square kilometers (nearly 4 million square miles) of ocean habitat!  Help us keep the momentum going join us today to protect the ocean and its wildlife! Link in bio.

Caption: To mark #LostSpeciesDay today take a glimpse at just a few of the many species that have gone extinct in recent centuries. Today over 46300 species around the world are threatened by extinction  that s 28% of all assessed species. If we don t take urgent action now we will see more and more species continue to disappear forever. Oceana campaigns to protect marine species threatened with extinction like sharks and North Atlantic right whale from their top threats. Join us to make a difference today! Source for all facts: IUCN Red List

Caption: Some bright comb jellies to add more light to your holidays.   Wondering how comb jellies produce such a beautiful display? Well these colorful animals possess specialized cells that produce photoproteins which generate the bioluminescent displays seen in some jellyfish.Although typically transparent many comb jellies give off blue and green bioluminescence. But unlike true jellyfish species comb jellies also shine without it! They do this with their cilia hair-like projections referred to as  combs  which is where comb jellyfish got its name. When light reflects off these combs it creates rainbow displays that can be seen in the ocean at night.    : Shutterstock

Caption: Today is #WorldBiodiversityDay!   Our oceans are home to plenty of wildlife that we know and love   but also many species that we don t know at all! It is thought that that 91% of ocean species are still not scientifically described. If we do not take urgent action to protect our oceans some of these species may go extinct before ever being discovered. That s why we work around the world to protect marine biodiversity safeguard our oceans and restore ocean abundance. Join us in making a difference for ocean wildlife with the #linkinbio!#BiodiversityDay #IBD2024 #Ocean #Wildlife #Biodiversity #InternationalDayforBiologicalDiversity

Caption: This #InternationalPolarBearDay we re celebrating one of the Arctic s most iconic animals!   Polar bears are perfectly suited for life on ice. They sport large padded claws and webbed toes which give them the ability to walk across the ice and swim as needed. They are specially evolved for the cold with black skin underneath their dense translucent fur coat that absorbs sunlight and keeps the bears warm! But being so well-adapted for the cold means they face a major threat: climate change. Warming temperatures cause more ice to melt earlier in the year making hunting increasingly difficult which causes bears to starve. The climate crisis is something we know how to combat and our oceans can be a key player in this battle. But immediate action is needed to tackle climate change to protect our future and our planets future. Join us in calling for urgent action today with the #linkinbio.#PolarBearDay #PolarBear #Arctic #Cold #BearCubs #PolarBears #ClimateChange #GlobalWarming #StandForOceans

Caption: We stand with everyone in the Philippines and Taiwan who are experiencing flooding from Typhoon Gaemi and hope you and your families are safe.Tragically one of the impacts of this typhoon has been the sinking of a Philippine oil tanker in Manila Bay. The ship was carrying about 370000 gallons of oil and if the situation is not contained quickly it could potentially become the worst oil spill in the country s history.Oceana s team in the Philippines is monitoring the situation closely and calling on the government to take swift action to control the spread of the oil and limit the impact to local habitats and wildlife. Looking forward we must protect local communities marine life and our oceans by moving away from dirty fossil fuels and towards clean renewable energy. : Philippines Coast Guard

Caption: Swooping down for the catch of the day.   Bald eagles live along the coasts of North America and were once hunted to near extinction. In 1972 the bald eagle was critically endangered in the United States. Fortunately conservation and management efforts - like the Endangered Species Act (ESA) - have been successful the species is expanding rapidly in both numbers and geographic area. Oceana campaigns to defend the ESA and other landmark U.S. conservation laws that safeguard marine life and our oceans from attack.Learn more about bald eagles with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio.#BaldEagle #MarineLife #Oceans #Eagle #SaveTheEaglesDay : Shutterstock/ BrunoFilipe

Caption: Female humpback whales form lasting bonds. Scientists have found that after spending half the year apart the same individual female humpbacks will reunite off the coast of Canadas Gulf of St Lawrence to spend the feeding season together. Caption: Just floating along!    Sea otter pups may be born in the water but that doesnt mean theyre ready for swimming right away! The pups dense coat traps air keeping it afloat. When mom needs to leave and go forage for food she will wrap her pup in kelp to keep it from drifting away while shes gone. After about two months sea otter pups start diving although theyll depend on their mom for a little while longer until about six months old.Learn more otter-ly adorable sea otter facts with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio. #SeaOtterAwarenessWeek : Wirestock Creators / Shutterstock

Caption: Happy #InternationalDayofForests!  Beyond their vital role in absorbing carbon dioxide kelp forests are home to some of the ocean s most unique creatures. From sea otters to weedy seadragons these towering underwater forests shelter marine life around the world.  Our on-the-water expeditions have taken us to kelp forests from California to Chile to learn more about the incredible biodiversity here and inform measures needed to protect these exceptional areas.  What s your favorite kelp creature?  : Sea otter video: Hanna Tor

Caption: Keeping cozy!   Female polar bears often give birth to twin cubs. These cubs are born in snowy dens which they stay in for the first several months of their life until they re ready for the world outside. The cubs stay with their mother for over two years to learn how to survive and hunt in the harsh environment in which they live! Learn more about polar bears with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio.

Caption: Spinner dolphins are known for their spectacular leaps out of the water!  These marine mammals can spin up to seven times in the air before landing back in the water. It is thought that the splash when they land may be a method of communicating with the rest of their pod! This enthusiastic spinning may also be a way to remove ectoparasites like remoras.  Learn more about these acrobatic animals with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Happy #WorldLizardDay from one very special reptile: the marine iguana!  Found in the Galapagos Islands the marine iguana is the only lizard that spends significant amounts of time at sea. These unique lizards can dive to depths of around 30 feet where they graze on algae sea grass and other marine plants that grow on the ocean floor. But the ocean water they swim in is cold- a problem for reptiles like these that can t internally regulate their body temperature. So after a swim marine iguanas need to bask in the sun to warm back up! Learn more about marine iguanas with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio.  : Shutterstock  #MarineIguana #Iguana #Lizard #Galapagos #GalapagosIslands #WildlifeWednesday #MarineLife #Ocean

Caption: The trumpetfish is certainly an unusual-looking fish! West Atlantic trumpetfish live near coral reefs where they feed mostly on other fish species. To hunt they are known to float vertically with their head down near elongated objects like long sponges or ropes for camouflage. Then they dart down to attack when they spot their prey! Trumpetfish are also known to camouflage by swimming next to large herbivorous fish in order to approach their prey without being seen.     Learn more about trumpetfish with the #linkinbio. : Shutterstock

Caption: Northern Peru has seen its fair share of hardships lately. On December 21 a large oil spill occurred by the port of Talara contaminating the surrounding area. The party responsible was identified as Petroperu. As they did not issue an alarm or immediate & appropriate contingency measures the oil consequently impacted an estimated 10000 square meters of sea. While the situation is now contained Petroperu has not been transparent about the amount of oil spilled. The spill has been devastating for marine life as well as those who depend on the ocean for their livelihood like artisanal fishers and tour operators.  Just a week later northern Peru also saw the arrival of abnormal strong waves creating devastating flooding and further impacting local fishers in this area. The impact of these events has affected thousands of people and their livelihoods. Oceana_Peru is calling for action to be taken to hold Petroperu accountable for the damage the oil spill has done. We also continue our work to support local artisanal fishers and coastal communities who depend on our oceans to survive.

Caption: Fewer than 100 Rice s whales remain making them one of the rarest whales on Earth. But instead of protecting them President Trump is prioritizing offshore drilling in their only home the Gulf of Mexico. An Executive Order signed in February removes a requirement for oil and gas company ships to avoid or travel slowly in areas where Rice s whales may be present. These extra precautions decrease the risk of extinction for these extremely rare whales that are already threatened by oil spills vessel strikes and noise pollution. These incredible whales deserve to be protected. We can t let dirty & dangerous offshore drilling come before the future of an entire species! Read more with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Illegal wildlife trade threatens thousands of species including mammals birds fish and even plants. Oceana campaigns to protect ocean species from illegal trafficking by working with local communities governments and other allies   and together we re making change.  In 2022 following campaigning by Oceana and others Peru became the first South American country to declare illegal wildlife trafficking as a form of organized crime giving Peruvian authorities more legal tools to enforce the law and penalize those operating criminal networks.Later that year after more than a decade of campaigning by Oceana and our allies the United States Congress passed a law to ban the buying and selling of shark fins officially removing the U.S. from the unsustainable global shark fin trade where fins from as many as 73 million sharks end up each year. Oceana continues partnering with communities to protect marine species around the world and ensure the health and sustainability of our oceans for future generations. #StandForOceans

Caption: #BREAKING: Today new estimates put the North Atlantic right whale population at around 372 individuals which means they are still at risk of extinction. These critically endangered whales need better protection from their top threats: boat strikes and entanglement in fishing gear. In just 2024 alone at least four right whales were killed by boat strikes and entanglement in fishing gear and four additional calves are missing and presumed dead. Each one of these deaths is a major blow to the population s ability to recover. The U.S. government MUST do more to protect these whales especially vulnerable calves and new mothers. POTUS needs to finalize the updated Vessel Speed Rule immediately. By failing to take action our leaders risk letting these iconic whales disappear   forever.Read our full statement with the #linkinbio. #RightWhaleToSave

Caption: Meet the largest seal in the world!  Southern elephant seals can be enormous with males weighing up to 11000 pounds. They get their name from their large nose that resembles an elephants trunk!These seals live in sub-Antarctic and Antarctic waters. While their population is currently stable there are some concerns about the potential impacts of intensive fishing on their food sources as well as the effects of ongoing climate change.Learn more about these enormous seals and how you can help protect them today with the #linkinbio. #WildlifeWednesday  : jjsupasit srisawthsak / Shutterstock  : Danita Delimont / Shutterstock  : Danita Delimont / Shutterstock

Caption: A juvenile humpback whale that has been entangled in fishing gear for months is finally free! The whale was first seen earlier this month with rope from fishing gear wrapped around its tail. Given the state of its health and injuries it s estimated that it may have been entangled for as long as six months. Fortunately a team from NOAA was able to find the whale and cut the rope freeing it from its entanglement. However even with the gear off scientists fear it may not survive the injuries it sustained. Entanglement in fishing gear is a top threat to endangered animals off the West Coast including humpback whales. Sadly 75% of reported whale entanglements are fatal as whales can drag heavy fishing gear for months hindering their ability to dive and feed and leading to starvation and infection. We hope this whale is one of the fortunate individuals to survive an entanglement. Whales deserve to have safe passage as they migrate and feed off our shores! Oceana campaigns for stronger protections for whales to reduce wildlife entanglements like this one and is pushing for  whale-safe  ropeless gear that is a viable way to keep fishermen on the water and is safer for whales and sea turtles.   : NOAA

Caption: While most coral species are immobile some can WALK. Marine biologists at Queensland University of Technology in Australia filmed little tiny 1-inch-long disc corals walking. They found that these little coral move like jellyfish   by twisting and contracting their muscles to inflate themselves before all of a sudden throwing themselves forward with the pressure of deflating. And how quickly are these things chugging along?? Well  not very. Dr. Lewis measured a whopping 8 inches covered by one of his corals in a whole day. They move because their current habitat is overcrowded full of waves that topple them over or not close to other corals to reproduce with!  : Lewis BM Suggett DJ Prentis PJ Nothdurft LD (2025) Walking coral: Complex phototactic mobility in the free-living coral Cycloseris cyclolites. PLoS ONE 20(1): e0315623. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0315623  2025 Lewis et al. Open access article.people qutrealworld

Caption: Tis the season  Christmas tree worms have crowns that resemble the fir trees that gave them their festive name. These crowns are used to absorb oxygen and filter food like phytoplankton from the surrounding water. Christmas tree worms live in corals that protect their soft bodies from predators. They stay hidden in the coral burrows with only their colorful crowns visible quickly disappearing if threatened! Learn more about these festive critters with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio. : Shutterstock#ChristmasTreeWorm #Holiday #MarineLife #Ocean #Christmas #Xmas

Caption: Protecting Patagonias Hidden Gem   Katalalixar   a far-flung maze of islands and fjords to the west of the Patagonian ice fields   is the ancestral homeland of the Kaw sqar people. Beneath its glacier-chilled surface is an underwater wonderland teeming with life.   Now we face the challenge of protecting this part of Patagonia and safeguarding Katalalixar from industrial threats. To do so we funded a story-gathering project with Kaw sqar residents in the town of Puerto Eden to document and map out their traditional knowledge of the local land and sea. The work then inspired a  cultural  expedition which paired Oceana staff with a five-member Kaw sqar family on a 15-day journey. The journey was far from easy   storms food shortages and treacherous seas tested our resilience. But it was all worth it to work towards our goal of persuading the government to bolster protections for this ecologically and culturally important region by designating it as a national park.   The expeditions footage was turned into a documentary film that premiered in January 2023 in order to shine a spotlight on the issue and generate support to  protect the marine ecosystem. We are proud to support the Kaw sqar residing in Puerto Eden in protecting their local land and sea! See more of the documentary with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Marine biodiversity is facing serious threats.By the year 2100 it is thought that more than half of the world s marine species will be threatened with extinction if significant changes are not made. This loss is not only heartbreaking but also reduces the ocean s ability to provide food maintain water quality and recover from other threats. We cannot afford to wait to protect our oceans & marine life. Thats why Oceana campaigns to deliver policy changes that increase marine biodiversity restore ocean abundance safeguard habitat and protect our oceans around the world. Learn more and #StandForOceans with us with the #linkinbio.    : MOHAMED ABDULRAHEEM / Shutterstock : Louisiana Governor s office : Roger Millan / Shutterstock

Caption: Happy #WorldMantaDay!  Oceanic manta rays can grow to astonishing widths of over 25 feet and can weigh up to 3000 pounds! They grow so big by filter feeding on massive amounts of tiny plankton as well as schools of small fish. Caption: The largest of the world s sea turtles leatherbacks have existed essentially unchanged since prehistoric times. But today despite being protected under the Endangered Species Act leatherback sea turtles are among the most endangered animals in the ocean specifically the Pacific population.These turtles face being caught accidentally in fishing gear as well as being targeted for their meat and eggs. Thankfully since these threats have been identified work is being done to address them! Oceana has successfully campaigned to protect leatherbacks and their habitat gaining them increased habitat protections under California s Endangered Species Act. We have also helped introduce regulations to transition various local fisheries away from gear prone to entangling marine life like drift gillnets and long line crab pots.We continue fighting to protect these titanic turtles and other threatened wildlife in our seas! #LeatherbackDay #SeaTurtleWeek

Caption: Boo - its a ghost crab!     Ghost crabs get their name from their pale coloration and their swift movement which seemingly bears a fleeting resemblance to a ghost. Caption: Happy #ManateeAppreciationDay!  These peaceful sea cows may have inspired mermaid legends but in reality they spend much of their days grazing on seagrass and floating effortlessly through the water.   Sadly Florida manatees continue  to face numerous threats including habitat loss and pollution the loss of seagrass beds   their primary source of food   and human activities such as boat strikes and entanglements in fishing gear.You can help protect these gentle giants! Symbolically adopt a manatee today and your donation will support our campaigns to protect manatees and our oceans from some of their biggest threats. Link in bio.

Caption: Pacific leatherback sea turtles roamed the earth with dinosaurs surviving for 100 million years virtually unchanged. But today they are the most endangered sea turtle in the Pacific Ocean with their population having declined 95% over the last 30 years. Back in February the California Ocean Protection Council authorized new funding for the state to help prevent whales and sea turtles like Pacific leatherbacks from becoming entangled in fishing gear following campaigning by Oceana and its allies. This included up to $650000 to advance innovative  ropeless fishing gear  in the state s commercial Dungeness crab fishery. Ropeless gear allows for fishers to both catch crab more often and do so with far less risk to ocean wildlife. This decision by California supports fishing practices that ensure whales and sea turtles can safely feed and migrate off the California coast. Oceana continues to campaign to protect Pacific leatherbacks whales and other ocean life from entanglement in fishing gear and other threats. #PacificLeatherbackConservationDay  : Doug Perrine / Alamy  #LeatherbackTurtle #PacificLeatherback #SeaTurtle #MarineAnimal #Ocean

Caption: HEARTBREAKING: In the past few weeks two humpback whales have been seen off the U.S. West Coast suffering devastating injuries from entanglements in fishing gear. One which was seen with rope wrapped around its tail thankfully has been disentangled although concerns still linger about its health. But the other is not so lucky   missing its entire tail the whale is critically wounded and unlikely to survive as it struggles to dive and feed. Entanglement in fishing gear is a top threat to whales and sea turtles. Once a whale is trapped in fishing gear it can drag the heavy  ropes and traps for weeks if not months before falling victim to its wounds. Fishery managers must do more to protect these majestic animals! Call for more to be done to protect whales from deadly entanglements today with the #linkinbio.  : NOAA : The Whale Museum. NMFS Permit #24359. Photo taken by Spencer Fire.

Caption: As we celebrate #WorldHabitatDay lets remember the importance of marine habitats around the world.  From providing food and shelter for countless species to supporting coastal communities healthy oceans are essential to both nature and people. Yet only about 8% of our oceans are currently protected.But we are making progress! In 2000 less than 1% of the waters off the countries where Oceana currently operates were protected. Today thanks to campaigning by Oceana and our allies about 17% of their waters are now protected.We are continuing to work toward the global goal of protecting 30% of ocean habitat by 2030. Join us in safeguarding our seas today with the #linkinbio.

Caption: This North Atlantic right whale is in serious jeopardy.Dropcloth an older whale with sightings going back to 1978  was spotted suffering from his fifth known entanglement in late July 2024. In poor condition Dropcloth s injuries are serious and without intervention he is tragically likely to die from this entanglement. Every day North Atlantic right whales must fight for their lives navigating waters where boat strikes and deadly fishing gear threaten their survival. With only 356 right whales left in the world including just 70 breeding females time is running out.  To save them from extinction we must act now! Add your name to protect the #RightWhaleToSave today. Link in bio.

Caption: Happy #GalentinesDay from these humpback whale BFFs!    Female humpback whales have long-lasting bonds. After spending half the year apart migrating to and from breeding grounds in tropical waters the same social groups of female humpbacks have been seen reuniting off the coast of Canada s Gulf of St Lawrence where they spend the feeding season together. These whales manage to find each other summer after summer.  : Jonas Gruhlke / Shutterstock #HumpbackWhaleAwarenessMonth #HumpbackWhale #Whales #MarineLife #BFF #Friends #Oceans

Caption: A WIN FOR WILDLIFE: Florida is banning the intentional release of balloons - balloons are one of the deadliest forms of plastic pollution for ocean wildlife.   We applaud the state for passing this important new law that helps protect marine life!   Balloons and their plastic ribbons tie-off disks clips and other attachments can be easily swallowed by endangered sea turtles seabirds and other ocean wildlife. In fact studies  show balloons rank among the deadliest plastic for ocean animals. Floridas new law will help save ocean wildlife from these preventable deaths!

Caption: Open wide! Basking sharks are the second-largest sharks in the world growing up to 40 feet long. Like the biggest shark in the world the whale shark these gentle giants are filter feeders and eat mostly tiny zooplankton. The sharks often feed close to the surface and can be seen  basking  there when the weather is good.Learn more with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio. #WorldBaskingSharkDay

Caption: TWO new North Atlantic right whale babies! Congrats to  Blackheart  and first-time mom Caterpillar who were both seen off the coast of Florida near Ponte Vedra with their new calves.  Calving season is an exciting time for these critically endangered whales but it s also very dangerous. Mother and calf pairs swim slowly and close to the water s surface to breathe. They are very susceptible to being hit by speeding boats which can cause injury or even death.Add your name to call for enforcement to protect right whales before it s too late! Link in bio. #RightWhaleToSave

Caption: THEN AND NOW: Back in 2017 little was known of Chile s Pisagua Bay seabed until Oceana and the uarturoprat decided to investigate. On our first expedition we were amazed by what we found. This vibrant area is home to coral banks manta rays Chilean jack mackerel and so much more. We knew right away: this place had to be protected   so we took action! Fast forward to 2023 our vision is finally a reality! Following three more expeditions and a scientific recommendation of protection Chile has officially established the Pisagua Sea Marine Protected Area (MPA). Spanning over 181500 acres this MPA safeguards not just marine habitats and species but also the livelihoods of local artisanal fishers who depend on these waters. Oceana worked closely with Pisagua s artisanal fishers to ensure the MPA s creation supports the ocean and their economy.  Pisagua Sea  is now the first MPA in Chile designed to both protect marine life and the people who rely on it. Dive into the full story and see how we made this incredible achievement happen at the #linkinbio.

Caption: This #WorldPenguinDay we re celebrating some very special seabirds!   Penguins may not be able to fly but the water is where they shine! These flightless birds use their wings as flippers to propel themselves through the ocean as they hunt for underwater prey like squid krill or fish.Penguins  iconic black and white coloration known as countershading serves as effective camouflage. Their black backs blend with the dark ocean when seen from above while their white bellies resemble lighter surface waters when viewed from below helping them evade potential predators.Celebrate these seabirds with a symbolic adoption today! Your gift will help power Oceana s campaigns to mitigate drivers of climate change by ending our dependence on dirty fossil fuels and single use plastic. Link in bio. #PenguinDay #Penguins #Seabirds #Ocean #MarineLife

Caption: Hermit crabs are known for carrying their home on their back!Their shells play a vital role in protecting the crabs soft abdomens. However hermit crabs don t craft these shells themselves. Instead they move into abandoned shells left behind by other sea creatures like snails whelks or periwinkles.Finding the right shell is important as well. A shell thats too large can leave a crab overburdened and underprotected while one thats too small constricts their growth. Learn more about these curious critters with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio.

Caption: New research highlights that Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) which were initially designed to safeguard marine life could also be a vital tool in addressing climate change.Research around natural carbon storage that happens in the ocean often referred to as  blue carbon  has typically focused on mangrove forests salt marshes and seagrass meadows. But this study argues that seabed sediments may hold greater potential for carbon storage and should also be considered for protection.See how Oceana is campaigning to protect ocean habitat and protect our climate with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Not all hermit crabs use shells as their home! Most species rely on borrowed shells to protect their soft abdomens but deepwater hermit crabs (family Parapaguridae) take a unique approach.   These crabs team up with sea anemones (family Hormathiidae) in an incredible partnership. Initially the crab inhabits a shell but over time the anemone overgrows and dissolves the shell forming a flexible covering that grows with the crab! This mutualistic relationship benefits both: the crab gets protection from predators like octopuses thanks to the anemones stinging tentacles while the anemone enjoys a free ride across the seafloor.  : Image courtesy of the NOAA Office of Ocean Exploration and Research 2015 Hohonu Moana.
Cleaned Caption: not all hermit crabs use shells as their home most species rely on borrowed shells to protect their soft abdomens but deepwater hermit crabs family parapaguridae take a unique approach these crabs team up with sea anemones family hormathiidae in an incredible partnership initially the crab inhabits a shell but over time the anemone overgrows and dissolves the shell forming a flexible covering that grows with the crab this mutualistic relationship benefits both the crab gets protection from predators like octopuses thanks to the anemones stinging tentacles while the anemone enjoys a free ride across the seafloor image courtesy of the noaa office of ocean exploration and research 2015 hohonu moana

Caption: With a bell that can be nearly 6 feet wide the lions mane jellyfish is one of the largest known species of jellyfish! These jellies use their long trailing tentacles to hunt fish and smaller jellyfish. They will spread their tentacles out wide then slowly sink down and try to ensnare their prey in a stinging net!  Learn more with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio.

Caption: These crafty crustaceans have their #Halloween costumes picked out do you?Decorator crabs will pick up materials from the seafloor and fix them to their shells for camouflage! They will use pretty much everything they can find including pieces of algae sponges leaves and even small living animals like anemones. They fasten these ornaments to curved bristles on the back of their shell which act almost like Velcro allowing the crab to take off old pieces and put on new ones.   Learn more about decorator crabs with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio. #SpookySeason

Caption: #BREAKING: Amazon is cutting its plastic use in North America following campaigning by Oceana.  Today Amazon announced that it has has replaced 95% of the plastic air pillows from delivery packaging in North America with 100% recycled paper filler   a move they say is expected to  avoid nearly 15 billion plastic air pillows annually. As the world s dominant e-commerce company Amazon s action to reduce plastic packaging is welcome news for the oceans and the company s customers said Matt Littlejohn Oceanas Senior Vice President of Strategic Initiatives. While this is a significant step forward for the company Amazon needs to build on this momentum and fulfill its multiyear commitment to transition its North America fulfillment centers away from plastic.Read more with the #linkinbio. #PlasticFreeAmazon

Caption: Today is #WorldEnvironmentDay!   The oceans connect us all. They cover two-thirds of our blue planet and contain most of the life on Earth. They are as important to us as they are vast. But the oceans face many threats   from overfishing habitat destruction oil and plastic pollution and the killing of threatened species like turtles whales and sharks. Thats why Oceana campaigns internationally to achieve policy-oriented & science-based victories to protect and restore our worlds oceans. And while we have won over 300 victories and protected nearly 4 million square miles of ocean theres still much more work that needs to be done for our planet! Join us to #StandForOceans today with the #linkinbio.   #GenerationRestoration

Caption: Do you recognize the dugong?At first glance they may look like manatees but dugongs are a creature all their own! One easy way to tell them apart? Caption: A new study has found that some large fishes use sharks to remove parasites. Research revealed that large open-ocean fish like tuna sometimes scrape against sharks to get rid of parasites and seem to prefer scraping against them even than other fish of the same species.These findings reveal new ways that species can be connected beneath the waves   which is both fascinating and highlights threats to ocean wildlife. Global shark populations are declining which the authors suggest may eventually lead to these fish having a harder time ridding themselves of parasites and threatening their overall health. Our oceans are an interconnected web of biodiversity. When one species declines many others can suffer as well. We must safeguard vulnerable marine species and promote biodiversity so that all ocean wildlife can thrive.

Caption: GREAT NEWS for Chile s waters! Chiles Committee of Ministers have unanimously rejected the Dominga Project! This controversial mining and port project has now been rejected for the third time. This is great news for the Humboldt Archipelago Marine Protected Area which is home to the iconic Humboldt penguin and many other marine species. For over a decade extensive scientific evidence has highlighted the risks the Dominga Project poses to Chile s waters communities and biodiversity. The project has also been linked to well-known cases of conflicts of interest. With this third rejection the #Archipi lagoHumboldt has received much-needed continued protection thanks to years of work from Oceana_Chile the communities of La Higuera artisanal fishers and many more who fought tirelessly to protect this pristine ecosystem. #NoADominga

Caption: ANOTHER BABY: Congrats to mom #4540 on her first calf! This is the third North Atlantic right whale baby identified so far this calving season. Mom and calf were seen off the coast off southern Virginia.   But these new mother-calf pairs face threats every day from speeding boats which can cause injury or death something #4540 s family knows all too well. You may remember her mother Juno. Last calving season Juno s calf died after being hit by a vessel. This critically endangered species needs urgent protections. Speak up for North Atlantic right whales today. Link in bio.

Caption: Hey! Did you know today is #AfricanPenguinAwarenessDay?  African penguins live on the rocky coastlines of southwest Africa the only penguin species on the continent.  The colonies they live in can be huge: up to 22655 breeding pairs! To communicate in such a crowded space these penguins call out to each other and these calls have earned them a special nickname: jackass penguins.African penguins will bray haw and yell vocalizations that bear a striking resemblance to those of donkeys. Each of these different sounds can be used for attracting potential partners or defending territory from rival encroachment!Learn more about these penguins - and the threats they face - with the #linkinbio.  : Quality Master / Shutterstock

Caption: NEWS FROM CALIFORNIA: The largest and most successful trial of pop-up fishing gear ever conducted on U.S. West Coast proves profitable for fishermen and safe for whales!   The California Dungeness crab fishery and whales are both in a state of crisis due to wildlife entanglements in fishing gear. Pop-up fishing gear is a gateway to keeping fishermen on the water in the spring when waters are closed to conventional crabbing gear.   The gear which was tested by 19 commercial California Dungeness crab fishermen brought in $1.6M of crab in spring 2024 during a time when fishers otherwise would not have been able to operate due to the risk of entangling endangered whales. These results prove this gear is successful profitable enforceable whale-safe and ready to restore a vibrant spring crab fishery! Learn more with the #linkinbio.   : Credit wildestanimal / Shutterstock  : Credit Sub Sea Sonics and Guardian Ropeless Systems

Caption: Your reminder of the day: Healthy oceans need sharks.Sharks play a very important role in keeping ocean ecosystems in balance. They keep prey populations in check and feed on old and sick fish helping to keep the overall population healthier. Oceana campaigns to end the trade for shark fins   which incentivizes overfishing and shark finning   as well as trade shark meat and other products that persists around the world. Saving sharks requires global protections and dedicated enforcement of them as well as an end to the devastating global shark fin trade.

Caption: HEARTBREAKING: Two North Atlantic right whales have been seen entangled in fishing gear off the coast of Massachusetts. One of these whales a juvenile male known as #5110 has a thick line wrapped around his head and back likely making it extremely difficult for him to feed. Sadly experts believe he is unlikely to survive this entanglement. The other whale an adult female known as #4120 was also seen with fishing lines wrapped around her mouth. Fortunately her injuries appear to be less severe and experts are optimistic she may be able to survive this entanglement. Scientists are monitoring these whales with the hope of mounting a response but dangerous disentanglement efforts depend on a lot of external factors like knowing the whales location weather and are not always possible or successful. These whales are not statistics they are living beings enduring unimaginable suffering caused by human activities  said Oceana s Gib Brogan.  NOAA is long overdue for establishing effective safeguards for North Atlantic right whales.  Read more with the #linkinbio. #RightWhaleToSave

Caption: Against all odds another North Atlantic right whale just pulled off a legendary move: having a calf!     At 18 years old  Check Mark  has given birth to her first calf. With around 370 individuals remaining and only 70 breeding females this baby is living proof that survival is the ultimate flex for these gentle giants. Mom Check Mark is especially impressive as she lost part of her right fluke earlier in life due to a vessel strike. To keep up the good fight this mother and calf will have to make it back up north avoiding speeding ships and fishing lines. Let s give these legends the protection they deserve. Link in bio. #RightWhaleToSave

Caption: Meet the blue glaucus one of the ocean s most dazzling little drifters!  This tiny sea slug floats upside-down on the ocean s surface using its vibrant blue belly to blend into the water s surface from above. But these free floaters are not defenseless! They have the ability to collect stinging nematocysts from their prey which they adopt as their own defense.  Learn more about these stunning sea slugs with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Caption: Exciting News!   We re thrilled to announce starboroughwine is returning as an Oceana partner in 2025. Over the last five years Starborough s support has helped Oceana achieve major milestones in ocean conservation with a combined donation of over $250000. Here s a look at some of what we ve accomplished together:   Mexico created the Southern Gulf of Mexico Reefs National Park the largest marine protected area in the Gulf of Mexico. This declaration follows multiple Oceana expeditions to the area.   Following campaigning by Oceana and allies Chile s congress passed the Benthic Law which will improve the management of kelp   a key ecosystem for marine life and an important resource for artisanal fishers.   In 2020 following more than a decade of campaigning by Oceana and our allies Spain s Supreme Court upheld the expansion of Cabrera Marine National Park Making it the second-largest marine protected area in the Mediterranean and the first to protect deep-sea corals. Now let s see the victories we can win for oceans together in 2025!

Caption: The Biden administration has committed to a plastic-free government! The administration announced that they will phase out single-use plastics across the federal government. They will first eliminate single-use plastic from its food service operations events and packaging by 2027 and then the entire government by 2035. The U.S. government is the world s largest purchaser of goods and services so this plan will make a real impact to protect our oceans climate and communities! We applaud this announcement from POTUS and look forward to the successful and swift elimination of single-use plastic across the government. Read more with #linkinbio.  #plasticfreeseas #BreakFreeFromPlastic #PlasticFreeJuly

Caption: #Paris2024 may be serving beverages in reusable cups but they re not winning any gold medals for the environment. At the 2024 Olympic games beverages are being sold to spectators in reusable packaging which could potentially replace millions of single-use plastic cups. But while leading sponsor theCocaColaCo touts its success at reducing plastic the reality is far from perfect. Many of these drinks are being poured into reusable cups from single use plastic bottles defeating the purpose of reuse in reducing plastic waste.  From a top global plastic polluter and major sports sponsor like theCocaColaCo much more is needed to address the plastic crisis. Despite the flaws the inclusion of reuse at Paris 2024 remains a beacon of hope for the oceans. Reuse done right CAN have a major impact on the environment and there is a growing trend for large events like this to use reusable packaging. Oceana is pushing for reuse to be done more and to be done better. Plastic pollution is an issue that impacts us all   athletes and spectators alike   and it s time for us to come together and ditch single-use plastic in favor of reuse. Learn more about our campaign to #RefillAgain and #BreakFreeFromPlastic with the #linkinbio.

Caption: It has now been 14 years since all forms of bottom trawling were prohibited in Belize s waters!   Bottom trawling is a highly destructive fishing practice where huge nets are dragged for miles along the seafloor bulldozing everything in their path. In December 2010 the Belize government banned trawling in the country s waters to protect its marine ecosystems and wildlife. Oceana_bze collaborated with the Prime Minister s administration at the time to help make this ban possible. This milestone stands as a testament to Belize s commitment to protecting marine ecosystems. However bottom trawling continues to threaten oceans globally. Oceana continues to work around the world to protect ocean habitat from bottom trawling and safeguard the future of our oceans.

Caption: #UPDATE: An oil tanker holding 1.4 million liters of oil sank in the Philippines Manila Bay on July 25 due to heavy rains and rough waters from Typhoon Gaemi. At least two other vessels have also sunk since then causing further oil pollution.It is estimated that the oil spill impacts 50% of Manila Bay with the oil pollution reaching Cavite Bulacan and Bataan. The spill can smother suffocate and kill important mangroves coral reefs and seagrass beds here which are essential for the breeding and feeding of numerous marine species in Manila Bay. We know what s at stake here: jobs food exports and even lives  said Oceana_phs Gloria Ramos.  Even after the oil pollution is cleaned up seafood may be contaminated for years. The people of the Philippines will be dealing with the impacts of this devastation long after the headlines fade and the government must do everything it can to mitigate this disaster as quickly as possible.  Read more with #linkinbio. :   Jilson Tiu / Greenpeace

Caption: Armando Paiva grew up fishing in Piura Peru like his father and grandfather. Here the first five nautical miles off Perus coast are critical to vibrant local marine life and sustaining artisanal fishers like Armando who provide 80% of the nations seafood. But much can change in a generation. Industrial fishers operating with an unselective take-all approach can use gear that causes harm to ocean habitat fisheries abundance and artisanal fishers  livelihoods. Armando and other artisanal fishermen knew that Peru s coast needed protecting and that they needed to take action to make that happen.Now Armando is a board member of the El Toril Artisanal Fishermen s Union in Piura and his career involves not only fishing but advocating on behalf of artisanal fishers in his community and building alliances with others across the country. Follow the #linkinbio to read the full story about the impact they are making and the major victory they won last year with the support of Oceana to support ocean abundance biodiversity and livelihoods in Peru! : Boats in the port of Matarani.   Oceana / Sebasti n Casta eda : Artisanal boats at sea off the coast of Peru.   Oceana / Andre Baertschi : Fish swimming in the coral reef off the coast of Peru.   Oceana / Eduardo Sorensen : Fishers going fishing in Cabo Blanco Peru.   Oceana / Andre Baertschi : Most artisanal fishers sail small boats no more than 30 feet long to catch anchoveta and other fish close to the coast using selective gear like hand-held nets and lines.   Oceana/Andre Baertschi : Fish swimming in the coral reef off the coast of Peru.   Oceana / Eduardo Sorensen

Caption: Sea turtles around the world are facing serious threats. Through our science-based campaigns Oceana is helping to protect sea turtles from habitat degradation plastic pollution being accidently caught in fishing gear and more. And together with allies we have achieved critical victories such as Californias enhanced protections for endangered Pacific leatherbacks and the creation of Bajos del Norte National Park which safeguards habitat for migrating turtles. Pledge to be an ocean advocate today to support our work protecting sea turtles and other ocean animals! Link in bio. #SeaTurtleWeek #Ocean #SeaTurtle #EndangeredSpecies #OceanAnimal #MarineLife #Turtle #StandForOceans

Caption: Its clear: when we drill we spill.Offshore drilling is a dirty and dangerous business that puts fragile ecosystems marine wildlife and our coastlines at constant risk of catastrophic oil spills. And these spills come with significant long-term effects with oil being found in sediment decades later and animals experiencing extreme sickness and eventual death. Oceana campaigns to protect our coasts and oceans from the threat of offshore drilling while promoting clean energy methods like responsibly sourced offshore wind.  And alongside our allies we have protected about 75000 miles of coastline in the United States and Belize covering more than 2.5 million square miles of ocean! But there s still more work to be done. Add your name to #ProtectOurCoast today with the #linkinbio!

Caption: Our trip to Campeche Bank in the Gulf of Mexico was truly stunning!  Our scientific expedition in partnership with CONANP helped us learn more about the status of the reefs in this area. Our preliminary results indicate healthy coral reefs off the coast of Campeche good news for the ecosystem!   Researchers on the expedition also found over 75 nesting areas for green turtles and hawksbill turtles as well as juvenile sea turtles indicating that this area is of high importance for these threatened animals.  This research will help us learn more about these coral reefs and provide a solid scientific basis for better protecting these sites that are home to such astounding biodiversity! OceanaMexico

Caption: Americas national parks are incredible and stunning but there s something that doesn t belong   plastic pollution.  Yet there is hope: secdebhaaland has ordered the phase out of single-use plastics in all national parks. Now they need to keep the momentum going and move swiftly to eliminate single-use plastics like plastic foam and bags. Caption: Today is International Day for Biological Diversity!   California s waters boast an incredible array of life from vibrant corals on the seafloor to humpback whales feeding off the coast. The ocean here is home to deep-sea coral gardens giant kelp forests nursery grounds for great white sharks and so much more making it a place of global importance for ocean wildlife. But these habitats and animals are threatened by indiscriminate fishing gears that can destroy fragile deep-sea corals and harm vulnerable species. This #BiodiversityDay stand up for California s wildlife and urge decision makers to protect this unique ocean ecosystem! Link in bio.

Caption: Its #BackToSchool and these fish are headed for schools too! Lots of fish species school by why? Being in a group also could mean more eyes looking out for threats!

Caption: Recent studies have discovered a whole new way plastic is impacting seabirds. Plasticosis as its been named is scarring in the stomach caused by injuries from ingesting plastic. This scarring which was found in a study on shearwater fledglings makes it harder for the birds to digest their food weakening them and putting them at risk of illness and injury. Right now Plasticosis has only been seen in seabirds but we know that plastic is everywhere   including in the food that we ourselves are eating. Plastic is choking our oceans and polluting our planet and urgent action is needed to reduce single-use plastic at the source or else we re going to continue to feel the impact in novel and horrifying ways like Plasticosis. Add your name to call for the United States to protect marine life and #BreakFreeFromPlastic with the #linkinbio.

Caption: It s #NationalStrawberryDay Did you know the ocean has its own version of wild strawberry fields? Meet the strawberry anemone! These tiny jewel-like anemones are rarely larger than the size of a nickel in diameter and often even smaller than a dime. Some live in clusters just below the tideline creating dazzling underwater colonies while others are solitary and show off their red luster in the shallow ocean depths. On our research expeditions we have encountered beautiful bunches of strawberry anemones particularly off California where they can completely cover rocks boulders and vertical rock walls. While their range extends as far as British Columbia a separate species of strawberry anemone in the Atlantic Ocean features a unique pattern that resembles strawberry seeds.

Caption: That s a wrap: we just concluded our second successful research voyage in Southern California s Channel Islands this year with partner Blancpain1735!  Once back on land we will start analyzing our findings to support better protections for #ocean #biodiversity in this globally important ecosystem from harmful gillnets.  These nets can be 20 football fields long (up to 6000 feet) are weighted to the seafloor to catch California halibut and white seabass and entangle a variety of wildlife including sea lions sharks and other fish. Stay tuned for more updates and to see how you can join us in protecting California s ocean waters!  #Blancpain1735 #BlancpainOceanCommitment #FiftyFathoms #BlancpainFiftyFathoms Oceana/Danny Ocampo

Caption: We took the UK Government to court last week over its reckless approval of oil & gas licenses in marine protected areas! Last week oceana_uk headed to London s High Court to challenge new North Sea oil & gas licenses. Oil companies are poisoning our seas polluting marine protected areas harming wildlife and fueling the climate crisis. The UK Government once promised to end new fossil fuel licenses now it s up to us to hold them accountable and fight for our oceans. The choice is clear:   A liveable planet & thriving seas   Or more oil more pollution more destruction Stay tuned for updates on the case in the coming weeks.

Caption: In recalling one of the scuba dives during our fall research expedition with partner blancpain1735 in California s Channel Islands JasonHeaton describes how he  descended into Caribbean-like visibility above and through the 20-metre-tall kelp as if into the canopy of a jungle.      Following sightings of a decorator crab with kaleidoscopic colors a curious and graceful harbor seal a bat ray cruising out of the kelp and more  This was one of those dives that you simply don t want to end.  The Channel Islands a chain of islands off Southern California are referred to as the Galapagos of North America due the incredible diversity of ocean life   Through a series of expeditions we are documenting and characterizing the vast array of California s renowned marine life and habitats in support of our campaign to reduce the entanglement of ocean animals in set gillnet fishing gear nets that span nearly a mile in length and are weighted to the seafloor to catch California halibut and white seabass.Our findings will reveal more about marine life in the Channel Islands and how to protect it from the threat of set gillnets. In addition to the incredible ocean life we encountered Jason also shares what life is like doing research on the water. Dive into the story with Jason and oceanographic_mag through the link in bio    : Jason Heaton courtesy of Oceana#Blancpain1735 #BlancpainOceanCommitment #FiftyFathoms #BlancpainFiftyFathoms

Caption: #DYK just a small amount of water can unlock hidden secrets in the ocean? In our second Southern California expedition this year with Blancpain1735 we re collecting samples to gather environmental DNA or eDNA that s found in the water. Analyzing this eDNA will allow us to identify virtually all the animals & plants passing through California s Channel Islands! Information like this provides key insights into the ecosystem since it allows us to learn about wildlife inhabiting the area even if we cannot see them.  : Oceana/Danny Ocampo #Blancpain1735 #BlancpainOceanCommitment #FiftyFathoms #BlancpainFiftyFathoms

Caption: North Atlantic right whales continue to be found entangled in Canadian waters. This summer three critically endangered whales have been spotted tangled in fishing gear along Canada s coast and only one has been successfully disentangled by responders. Each whale was dragging ropes in its mouth and some also had lines wrapped around their bodies and flippers. When whales get lines trapped in their mouth it can seriously impact their ability to feed and dive which can be life-threatening. North Atlantic right whales migrate from the warm waters off Florida and Georgia traveling along the East Coast of North America to feed in Canadian waters. Along their journey they face numerous threats including entanglement in fishing gear and the danger of being struck by speeding ships. With only around 356 of these whales left alive we are running out of time to pass essential protections to save the North Atlantic right whale from extinction. Speak up for the #RightWhaleToSave before it s too late with the #linkinbio.

This plastic  commonly used in takeout containers cups and packing peanuts   is made with toxic chemicals including those likely to cause cancer. But it doesn t stop there. Caption: #BREAKING: Another North Atlantic right whale has been seen entangled in fishing gear.  Shelagh was recently spotted with in Canada s Gulf of St. Lawrence with fishing gear stuck in her mouth. Researchers are determining if a disentanglement mission is possible but disentangling whales is dangerous work and can t fix the bigger issue: far too many North Atlantic right whales are getting caught up in fishing gear and dying.  Entanglements like this are one of the biggest threats to these critically endangered whales. Proper regulations must be put in place by the United States and Canada to prevent entanglements and simultaneously allow fisheries to operate in a truly sustainable way before it is too late for this species.  Add your name to call for more to be done to protect the #RightWhaleToSave with the #linkinbio!

Caption: Watching a school of fish swim in perfect harmony is mesmerizing but have you ever wondered why they move so seamlessly together? 1  To avoid predators. Swimming in sync makes it harder for predators to focus on a single fish reducing the chances of an attack. By sticking together they create a confusing ever-shifting mass that keeps them safer. 2  To save energy.Much like migrating birds fish move in unison to travel more efficiently. When swimming together the hydrodynamics of the fish school can allow them to swim using less energy than if they were swimming on their own. 3  To feed.More eyes mean a better chance of spotting food! Schooling also allows fish to venture into areas they might avoid alone as there s safety in numbers.

Caption: The 2023   2024 North Atlantic right whale calving season has ended. Swipe through to see how it went. Caption: Did you know mangrove forests:   Capture carbon   Serve as a natural defense for coasts against flooding & erosion   Provide a home for many species   Are a source of food water quality improvement and livelihood for local communities But more than 35% of the world s mangroves are gone and in the Philippines that number is even higher: over 50% of mangroves have been destroyed. By passing the National Coastal Greenbelt/Integrated Coastal Management Act we can protect mangroves benefit local communities and safeguard our planet. #WorldWetlandsDay

Caption: HEARTBREAKING: Recently a 10-day old northern royal albatross chick like this one died from eating plastic   that its parents unwittingly fed it.Unable to fly or find their own food young albatross chicks depend on mom and dad to head out to sea and bring back food. But more and more albatrosses are eating something else instead   plastic. And this can be deadly. Digesting sharp bits of plastic can cause internal cuts leading to bleeding and infection and it can also block the bird s digestive system leading to starvation. And it s going to keep happening to seabirds around the world if we keep flooding our oceans with unnecessary single-use plastic. Our plastic consumption has become a global crisis with wildlife like this baby albatross paying the price. Urgent action is needed to reduce single-use plastic at the source and protect our planet. Add your name to call for global leaders to #BreakFreeFromPlastic today with the #linkinbio.  : A northern royal albatross chick the same species of the chick that died from ingesting plastic earlier this year. Credit: Adwo / Shutterstock #WorldSeabirdDay #PlasticFreeJuly
Cleaned Caption: heartbreaking recently a 10day old northern royal albatross chick like this one died from eating plastic that its parents unwittingly fed itunable to fly or find their own food young albatross chicks depend on mom and dad to head out to sea and bring back food but more and more albatrosses are eating something else instead plastic and this can be deadly digesting sharp bits of plastic can cause internal cuts leading to bleeding and infection and it can also block the bird s digestive system leading to starvation and it s going to keep happening to seabirds around the world if we keep flooding our oceans with unnecessary singleuse plastic our plastic consumption has become a global crisis with wildlife like this baby albatross paying the price urgent action is needed to reduce singleuse plastic at the source and protect our planet add your name to call for global leaders to #breakfreefromplastic today with the #linkinbio a northern royal albatross chick the same species of the chick that died from ingesting plastic earlier this year credit adwo shutterstock #worldseabirdday #plasticfreejuly

Caption: Today is #WorldReefAwarenessDay!   These stunning shots are from Bajos del Norte National Park the largest protected area in the Gulf of Mexico. In 2021 and 2022 Oceana led multiple scientific expeditions to this area with our expedition partner Blancpain1735 to highlight the importance of this biodiverse habitat. The research derived from these trips served as the basis for this protected area s creation. Oceana continues to campaign around the world to learn more about coral reefs and other exceptional underwater habitats and gather evidence to win their protection! #NationalOceanMonth #OceanMonth #OceansMonth #AwakenNewDepths #NationalOceansMonth

Caption: In partnership with Blancpain1735 our scuba diving team is conducting surveys to document fish biodiversity & habitats around Southern California s furthest offshore islands! Together with eDNA collection these surveys will advance the understanding of biodiversity in the Channel Islands and provide scientific support to better protect ocean life from the threat of entanglement in set gillnets. Set gillnets can be 20 football fields long (up to 6000 feet) are weighted to the seafloor to catch California halibut and white seabass and entangle a variety of wildlife including sea lions sharks and other fish.  Oceana/Danny Ocampo and Jason Heaton courtesy of Oceana#Blancpain1735 #BlancpainOceanCommitment #FiftyFathoms #BlancpainFiftyFathoms

Caption: Why Lobster is Off the Menu in Brazil   If you found yourself on the beaches of Cear  Brazil you might be tempted to try one of the main delicacies of the Brazilian Northeast: lobster. But right now that s not an option. From November 1st to April 30th lobster fishing is strictly off-limits a crucial pause that allows populations to recover after years of overfishing. And as of February 1st even selling lobster in Brazil is illegal. Why? Because beneath the waves something crucial is happening: lobsters are reproducing.   Without this seasonal break the future of lobster (and the thousands of families who rely on it for their livelihood) would be in jeopardy. Oceana s 2019 stock assessment of red lobsters highlighted the urgency of this issue mobilizing artisanal fishers industry leaders and allies to support catch limits. Lobster is more than just a delicacy it s a lifeline for over 15000 families in Brazil.  The closed season is one of the main tools for ensuring the sustainability of the species  says artisanal fisherman Tobias Soares.  When we respect these rules we are defending the lobster and our livelihood.   : Oceana/Christian BragaOceanaBrasil

Caption: Meet the ocean s ultimate deep divers: elephant seals!  There are two species of elephant seals: Northern elephant seals and Southern elephant seals. These massive marine mammals get their name from the males  large trunk-like noses which they use to produce load roaring calls.But their size isn t the only thing that makes them impressive. Elephant seals can also dive almost a mile deep in search of squid and fish to eat!Learn more about enormous elephant seals with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Caption: Plastic pollution is having a devastating impact on Brazils marine life.Oceanabrasils new report Fragments of Destruction: the impacts of plastic on Brazil s marine biodiversity reveals some alarming facts about the dangers of plastic to marine life. Produced in collaboration with Brazilian scientists the report also highlights the staggering amount of plastic that Brazil contributes to the global plastic crisis.Oceanabrasil is campaigning for necessary measures for Brazil to address single-use plastic pollution including the ban of problematic disposable items and the establishment of reuse and effective recycling or composting. Read the full report and learn more about our work to #StopThePlasticTsunami with the #linkinbio.

Caption: UPDATE: The recent oil spill in Northern Peru is still contaminating ecosystems and impacting communities. Transparency and action is needed to understand the cause of this spill and address the devastating impact it has had. According to a recent report  The Shadow of Hydrocarbons  over 130 oil spills have occurred in Piura Peru in the last 20 years which averages out to over 6 events a year. Its cumulative impact on marine ecosystems is devastating affecting both biodiversity and economic activities dependent on the sea. Oceana_Peru is continuing to work to hold Petroperu accountable for the damage the oil spill has done and for the company to clean the ecosystem it has contaminated. We also continue our work to support local artisanal fishers and coastal communities who depend on our oceans to survive.

Caption: A concerning study reveals that Chile leads in whale deaths caused by ship collisions with 50 cases in the last decade. The most affected species are the fin whale humpback whale sei whale and blue whale.The researchers recommend protecting areas like the Humboldt Archipelago where large whale populations are found and vessel traffic is still low. They also suggest reducing ship speed and adjusting navigation routes to prevent collisions.  Dr. Susannah Buchan (susiebuchan) oceanographer and co-author of the study explains more in this video.

Caption: Weve completed the first part of our expedition to the Canary Islands for scientific research on ocean restoration!For 10 days we studied this area making a total of 55 dives with a remotely operated vehicle to better evaluate the health of the ecosystem and discover the biodiversity that call it home. Later this year well embark on the second part of this project to continue our research in this region.So far we have gathered invaluable data that promises to lead to fascinating results and were excited to learn more about how we can best protect this marine ecosystem!

Caption: Have you ever heard of marine snow?    It may look like fluffy white snowflakes falling beneath the surface of the ocean but it s actually a shower of dead plankton waste and organic matter drifting down to the ocean s depths. This  snowfall  sustains deep-sea life and plays a crucial role in the planet s carbon cycle.   Learn more with oceana_canada s recent blog - link in bio!

Caption: Last November a beaked whale calf died a heartbreaking death after ingesting a plastic balloon.Far too many marine animals are suffering from the impacts of plastic flooding our oceans. Thats why Oceana campaigns to stop plastic pollution at the source advocating for and getting legislation like balloon bans enacted. And just a few weeks ago Florida passed a new law banning the intentional release of balloons helping to protect Floridas shorelines and ocean wildlife from balloon pollution!  Learn more about our work for #PlasticFreeSeas with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Hawksbill turtles are super snackers!Just by eating these sea turtles help keep their coral reef homes healthy. While they have a varied diet the hawksbills primary food is sponges. In some areas turtles feeding on these sponges help keep the sponge population under control allowing reef-building corals to have enough space to grow. Caption: Always at ease at sea Sidneia Lusia da Silva already knew at the age of 10 what her destiny would be: to be a fisherwoman!   Even as a child growing up among 13 brothers and sisters in the northeast coast of Brazil Sidneia never got seasick when she went fishing.  I wake up and look at the sea and the sea gives me a strength that I have never found anywhere else  she says.  Come rain or shine fishing is where I make my living and what makes me happy.  However lobster fishing Sidneia s main source of livelihood has faced challenges. A 2019 assessment by Oceana revealed that the red lobstery fishery was on the verge of collapse. Oceana s analysis and campaigning helped to mobilize artisanal fishers fishing industries and other allies to support implementing catch limits which would help recover the lobster populations and support local fishing communities. These science-based catch limits were implemented earlier this year for the 2024 season a major win for our oceans and for fishers like Sidneia! OceanaBrasil   : Sidneia Lusia da Silva on the beach in Icapu /Cear   : Sidneia Lusia da Silva on the beach in Icapu /Cear   : Lobster in Icapu  Cear : Praia da Redondas beach in Icapu /Cear

Caption: Narwhals are famous for their long spiral tusks. But have you ever wondered what they actually use them for? Scientists have known for a while that males uses their tusks to compete for females but new footage reveals these tusks have way more uses! Researchers captured narwhals using their tusks to forage and to engage in social and play behavior   something that has never been seen before! These discoveries are deepening our understanding of narwhals and highlight just how much we have to learn about these elusive Arctic whales.  : O Corry-Crowe et al. (2025). Use of tusks by narwhals Monodon monoceros in foraging exploratory and play behavior. Frontiers in Marine Science 12. https://doi.org/10.3389/fmars.2025.1518605

Caption: The grooved brain coral is one of the oceans most iconic corals! Its deep maze-like grooves aren t just for looks this coral provides vital structure and shelter for marine life hosting creatures like urchins and algae while also serving as a snack for fish like parrotfish.  Found in the Caribbean and Western Atlantic it grows slowly but can live for hundreds of years!Learn more about this cool coral with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Caption: Its #SeaMonth in Chile! #MesDelMarIn 2000 less than 1% of Chile s ocean was protected. But today over 40% of its marine areas are under some form of protection   great progress for our oceans! For over 20 years Oceana has worked to protect Chiles waters and were not slowing down. Today Oceana_Chile is campaigning to:  Protect marine habitats including underwater forests  Increase transparency and regulation in the salmon industry  Reduce plastic pollution  Help recover Chilean fisheriesLearn more about our work and campaigns in Chile with the #linkinbio!

Caption: European Union law requires countries to allocate fishing opportunities based on transparent and objective criteria taking into account the benefits for society the economy and the environment. However in practice most countries distribute fishing quotas primarily to those with a history of catching the most fish favoring industrial fleets over artisanal vessels. This approach harms both coastal fishing communities and the marine environment.oceanaeuropes photo exhibition showcasing low-impact fishers across Europe took place from 30 September to 4 October in front of the European Parliament in Brussels. It introduced David Muireann Neily and Primitivo   artisanal fishers dedicated to providing fresh high-quality seafood while preserving the sustainability and heritage of their coastal communities.Take a look at some of the stunning pictures featured as well as moments from the inauguration. Link in bio for all pictures and information!#MakeFishingFair #OceanaEurope #SustainableFisheries #ArtisanalFishers

Caption: Dive down a little deeper into the twilight zone!Below the surface layer of the ocean lies the mesopelagic zone also known as the twilight zone. With only faint sunlight shining through animals in these places must develop other strategies to survive and adapt to the low light increasing atmospheric pressure and low temperatures. Swipe through to see a few of the animals that travel through these waters!  Our trip to the twilight zone is part of our journey to explore the ocean depths this #OceansMonth. We ll be diving deeper in our ocean each week to highlight some of the incredible wildlife that call our oceans home! Learn more about these ocean animals and more with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio. #AwakenNewDepths #NationalOceansMonth

Caption: A huge plastic tsunami has popped up in Brazil outside the cidades_lixozero Congress! The work of mundano_sp this piece of art is designed to highlight how massive the plastic crisis has become. As the largest producer of single-use plastics in Latin America it is urgent that Brazil leads the change and revises the way it produces and consumes plastic. That s why more than 80 Brazilian organizations are part of the #StopThePlasticTsunami campaign led by OceanaBrasil! Together we are calling for support for Congress in Brazil to advance and approve a bill that focuses on the problem of plastic pollution at the root: its production and supply. For the sake of our oceans our communities and our planet we must #BreakFreeFromPlastic!
