Caption: DID YOU KNOW: All the plastic products we use in our daily lives start as plastic pellets. An estimated 250000 tons of these pea-sized plastic pellets end up in the oceans every year! These pre-production pellets also called nurdles are frequently spilled during production and transportation and end up in our oceans and waterways. And once they re there they are very difficult to clean up due to their small size. The U.S. needs more tools to keep these plastic pellets from entering our oceans! Urge your members of Congress to protect our oceans by cosponsoring the Plastic Pellet Free Waters Act today with the #linkinbio.   : Images by KT / Shutterstock

Caption: Over a third of the world s fish populations are depleted    but the impacts of overfishing arent spread evenly.In regions like West Africa and Southeast Asia where much of the population lives by the sea and relies on fishing for their livelihoods the challenges are greater. Its a tangled story of industrial fishing local livelihoods and climate change.  In Ghana small-scale fishing communities with deep connections to the sea struggle to catch the fish they need compared to industrial vessels.   In Senegal an overcrowded fishing industry combined with the impacts of climate change is both harming fish populations and sending ripples through local economies.   In Malaysia even in one of the countrys oldest fishing villages there are less fish to go around.Any efforts to recover fisheries must prioritize equity. Thats why Oceana is preparing to launch new campaigns to empower the people who rely the most on fish to develop solutions that work for them. Read more in our blog with the #linkinbio.

Caption: From the brink of extinction: The brown pelican s comeback Once nearly wiped out by the feather trade then poisoned by pesticides the brown pelican is the original success story of the Endangered Species Act (ESA). In the late 1800s these iconic coastal birds were hunted relentlessly for their feathers prized in high fashion. Then in the 1950s they faced a new threat: DDT. This toxic pesticide made its way up the food chain causing pelican eggshells to thin and break before chicks could hatch. Their numbers plummeted. Listed as endangered in 1970 under the Endangered Species Act the brown pelican s turning point came when DDT was banned in the United States in 1972 and with habitat protection thanks to the ESA. As DDT contamination levels dropped their populations rebounded. By 2009 they were fully removed from the Endangered Species List. Today brown pelicans soar along North America s coasts a powerful reminder that the Endangered Species Act works. But now following proposed cuts to NOAA s ability to defend threatened wildlife this critical law is also under attack.   Join us in defending the Endangered Species Act because every species deserves the same chance at survival that the brown pelican had! Link in bio.

Caption: Recycling alone cannot solve the ocean plastic pollution crisis.A meager 9% of all plastic waste generated has been recycled. We know that we can t recycle our way out of this mess especially as plastic production is expected to triple by 2050.That s why Oceana is campaigning to stop plastic pollution at the source   by passing local state and national policies that reduce the production and use of unnecessary single-use plastic that is flowing into our oceans while also working with companies to move to refillable and reusable systems.If plastics are significantly reduced at the source less plastic waste will enter the oceans where it poses a grave threat to marine life. Join us in our campaigns for #PlasticFreeSeas with the #linkinbio! : OCEANA / Yulia Smishkewych #StandForOceans #NationalRecyclingDay #AmericaRecyclesDay #Recycling #SingleUsePlastic #BreakFreeFromPlastic #Oceans

Caption: A Legacy of Courage and Community Jos  Alberto Lima Ribeiro known as Beto Pescador comes from a generation of traditional fishermen from Praia do Canto Verde on the eastern coast of Brazil. His journey into artisanal fishing began at the age of 8 inspired by stories from seasoned fishermen. Among them the tale of the Jangada de S o Pedro a daring voyage in 1941 to demand labor rights from the President of Brazil ignited his lifelong passion for advocacy. Now Beto is at the forefront of modern struggles fighting for fair fishing policies and the preservation of traditional fishing communities. Among what he works towards is a new Fishing Law that will benefit both small-scale fishers and our oceans. With support from OceanaBrasil a bill that would modernize the current Fishing Law was just filed in Brazil s Senate. This bill was drafted with input fishers and shellfish gatherers from traditional communities and is a promising step forward for responsibly managed fisheries and the health of our oceans!  We need to put forward our point of view on sustainability and environmental preservation in order to improve fishing in general says Beto. Only if we are organized will we be able to be heard and have the space we deserve.  Read more with the #linkinbio.  : Beto Pescado. Credit: Oceana/Andressa Anholete : Beach in Cear  Brazil. Credit: Bento Viana Fotografia : Boat off the coast of Cear  Brazil. Credit: Bento Viana Fotografia

Caption: Most EU citizens want political leaders to prioritize ocean protection new polls reveal.This survey conducted across seven EU countries highlights that European citizens place high importance on environmental matters and ocean protection. Restrictions against destructive fishing in protected areas like bottom trawling are one way to achieve this. Currently bottom trawling is still allowed in marine protected areas around Europe. We are calling on the new EU political leaders to take action and safeguard our oceans marine life and the future of ocean-dependent communities!Learn more and see full survey results with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Before it was blue was our ocean GREEN?    For Earth s first several billion years our oceans were green. And now rising temperatures are fueling massive phytoplankton blooms turning parts of the ocean green again. This isn t just a color change   it s a signal of a rapidly changing marine ecosystem a warning sign that we re witnessing history before our eyes.  Learn about how we fight for the blue ocean we know and love at oceana.org Article: popularmechanics Feb 2025  #ClimateChange #ClimateAction #OceanScience

Caption: Every day over 200 tons of unnecessary plastic are generated from e-commerce in Mexico City.  Earlier this month Oceana  Avaaz and UNAM students delivered 30000 citizen signatures calling for the Congress of Mexico City to approve a bill that would reduce the single-use plastic that comes from e-commerce. This bill would make a big impact protecting marine life and our oceans from plastic pollution but right now it s stuck in the Legislative Branch awaiting approval. Every minute of delay is more unnecessary plastic waste! It s time for Mexico City to approve this vital bill and act for plastic-free shipping. #Env osSinPl sticos OceanaMexico

Caption: Victory for Brazil with new lobsters catch limits implemented!   Since the 1950 s red spiny lobster and green lobster populations in Brazil have been in steep decline. The potential collapse of this fishery would not only impact these marine species and our oceans but also local artisanal fishers who depend on this activity for their food and livelihood.  For years fishers scientific community industry stakeholders and nonprofit organizations like Oceanabrasil have been working together to try and address this issue. Now through scientific studies stock assessments and coordination with fisherfolk we have helped convince the government to finally act towards a sustainable lobster fishery!  Tobias da Silva a local lobster fisherman emphasizes the importance of adhering to the newly established regulations: Now what needs to be done is to respect the rules. It needs to start with us fisherfolks this respect. And the government needs to do its part. If everyone does their part we ensure that the lobster species do not come to an end.

Caption: VICTORY: Mexico has created a new marine protected area!   The Southern Gulf of Mexico Coral Reefs National Park protects over 4 million hectares (over 15000 square miles) of important marine ecosystems. The declaration follows three Oceana scientific expeditions in this area to learn more about the ecosystem and help find a way for this protected area to benefit local communities fishers and wildlife.

Caption: According to EU laws its citizens cannot support or benefit from illegal fishing. However Member States do not have a comprehensive system in place to identify foreign ownership of fishing vessels. Many companies including those with EU owners hide behind complex corporate structures to exploit fisheries resources in non-EU countries where controls might be weaker.Fighting illegal fishing requires acting against those who ultimately benefit from it and the solution is making key information public!    Learn more in a new article by FinancialTimes with Oceana s insights. Link in bio.

Caption: Hundreds of sea lions dolphins and seabirds are washing up dying or already dead along the Southern California coast because of a toxic algal bloom. And it s not just wildlife suffering   the algal bloom is also poisoning our seafood and disrupting our fisheries. But at a time when we need more research and response capabilities the current administration is cutting government resources.We need a fully funded staffed and resourced NOAA to protect marine life coastal communities and the economies that depend on a healthy ocean! Join us   demand action now. Link in bio. nytimes latimes marinemammalcare

Caption: DID YOU KNOW: Many of the plastic products that we use in our daily lives like plastic bottles or bags start as nurdles   tiny plastic pellets about the size of a pea. But because they re so small nurdles spill easily and frequently end up polluting the environment. In fact an estimated 10 trillion nurdles pollute marine ecosystems worldwide each year! The U.S. needs more tools to keep these plastic pellets from entering our oceans! Urge your members of Congress to protect our oceans by cosponsoring the Plastic Pellet Free Waters Act today with the #linkinbio.  : Images by KT / Shutterstock

Caption: The U.S. is failing North Atlantic right whales which are on the brink of extinction with only around 370 whales left. Now due to the United States  inaction the Commission for Environmental Cooperation (cecnorthamerica) part of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) includes representatives from each country voted unanimously to investigate U.S. shortcomings to protect North Atlantic right whales. Oceana says: hold the U.S. accountable and protect the #RightWhaleToSave! Read more with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Mangrove forests:   Capture and store carbon   Protect communities from heavy rains storms and erosion by being powerful coastal defenders  Provide nesting nursery and feeding grounds for a variety of species  Are a source of food water quality improvement and livelihood for local communitiesBut despite their critical importance mangroves remain undervalued and severely threatened. Thats why Oceana campaigns to #RestoreMangroveForests in the Philippines in 2022. Our goal is to secure the approval of a national law to facilitate the restoration and preservation of mangroves and beach forests to combat coastal erosion and mitigate the adverse effects of climate change. Learn more about our work with the #linkinbio! #WorldMangroveDay Oceana_ph

Caption: Today alone almost 1 billion disposable plastic items were produced in Brazil.Every second 15000 of these items are produced in Brazil. We continue to create single-use plastic items that are made from a material that can last centuries but are thrown away after just one use. Following this path is to keep polluting our oceans and harming our health and the environment.  As the largest producer of this material in Latin America it is urgent that Brazil leads the change and revises the way it produces and consumes plastic. Thats why were calling for Brazil to pass a bill focusing on the problem of plastic pollution at the root! If you live in Brazil add your name to support the Plastic-Free Ocean Bill with the #linkinbio!#PlasticFreeOcean #StopThePlasticTsunami OceanaBrasil #PlasticFreeJuly

Caption: The recovery of northern cod is under threat by a recent decision from Canadas Fisheries Minister. After a 32-year moratorium the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans has announced the reopening of the commercial northern cod fishery along with increasing the Canadian fishing quota by 38.5%.The decision made as the stock barely moved out of the critical zone poses significant risks to the future recovery of this iconic fish population and a centuries-old fishery that is vital for Newfoundland and Labrador ocean ecosystems and coastal communities. It ignores scientific advice and the urgent need to address the impacts of decades of overfishing and short-sighted fisheries management. We are deeply concerned with this short-sighted decision as opening the commercial fishery puts the stock at significant risk and undermines efforts to rebuild healthy oceans and coastal communities. Read oceana_canada s full press release with the #linkinbio.
Cleaned Caption: the recovery of northern cod is under threat by a recent decision from canadas fisheries minister after a 32year moratorium the minister of fisheries and oceans has announced the reopening of the commercial northern cod fishery along with increasing the canadian fishing quota by 385the decision made as the stock barely moved out of the critical zone poses significant risks to the future recovery of this iconic fish population and a centuriesold fishery that is vital for newfoundland and labrador ocean ecosystems and coastal communities it ignores scientific advice and the urgent need to address the impacts of decades of overfishing and shortsighted fisheries management we are deeply concerned with this shortsighted decision as opening the commercial fishery puts the stock at significant risk and undermines efforts to rebuild healthy oceans and coastal communities read oceana_canada s full press release with the #linkinbio

Caption: VICTORY: New England cod nursery protected from proposed scallop dredging! Weve won protection for an important cod nursery on Georges Bank in New England. With our allies Oceana beat back an attempt by the U.S. scallop fishery to open this protected area to the dragging of heavy dredges along the seafloor to catch scallops which would damage habitat and scoop up other non-target marine life. Oceana persuaded the New England Fishery Management Council that this type of fishing is in direct conflict with preserving the area for spawning growth and feeding of Atlantic cod American lobster and Atlantic herring. Learn more about our campaigns to stop overfishing and promote responsible fisheries with the #linkinbio.   #StandForOceans

Caption: IMAGINE THIS: If single-use plastics had been around during these times they could STILL be around today. Mass production of plastics began to rise in the 1950 s so it s true that they weren t hanging around at events like the signing of the Declaration of Independence. However scientists believe that these plastics may take centuries to fully degrade so if they HAD been there these same plastics could still be around today. And yet some of these plastics are only actually in use for a few minutes before they are discarded. It s clear: the concept of single-use plastics doesn t make sense! Add your name to help our planet #BreakFreeFromPlastic today with the #linkinbio.

Caption: Have you been told that a disposable item is better because its made of cardboard or poly-paper?Many times cups and wrappers are made of poly-paper which makes them seem more environmentally friendly. However these products are still single-use plastics as they contain a plastic layer that makes them waterproof.Chiles Single-use Plastics Law aims to address this issue. Starting in 2026 reusable items will be required for on-site consumption in food establishments reducing the distribution of disposables that often end up as waste in cities and oceans.oceana_chile is part of a coalition with a variety of allies working to promote the Single-Use Plastics Law and support its implementation. Learn more about our work to #GetOverPlastics with the #linkinbio! #SuperaElPl stico

Caption: #DYK water samples can unlock long-kept ocean secrets? On our Southern California expedition we re collecting samples on our expedition with Blancpain1735 to gather environmental DNA or eDNA that s found in the water. Through analyzing this eDNA we can learn more about all kinds of wildlife that inhabit or traverse Californias Channel Islands. These samples provide insights into the ecosystem beyond typical dives revealing microscopic organisms and creatures that have passed through! #Blancpain1735 #BlancpainOceanCommitment #FiftyFathoms #BlancpainFiftyFathoms

Caption: #BREAKING: A newborn North Atlantic right whale has been spotted with its mother #2430  Minus One  off Amelia Island in Florida! This is Minus One s fourth known calf and the two will stay in the waters of the Southeastern United States for several months while the calf grows and learns from mom.   Over 20 years ago Minus One was fortunate to survive a vessel strike which left her with lacerations along her right side. But although she was lucky then theres no guarantee that her luck will continue for her & her new calf. Far too many North Atlantic right whales are injured or killed by speeding boats and new mother-calf pairs are especially vulnerable. Speak up to call for stronger protections for the #RightWhaleToSave today! Link in bio.

Caption: Combating plastic pollution involves reducing single-use plastic production and strengthening more sustainable alternatives. A recent study in Brazil by OceanaBrasil and WWFBrasil found that in addition to the benefits to the environment these changes can also boost the economy and drastically reduce carbon emissions! Brazil is the 8th largest plastic polluter in the world. Caption: BIG WIN FOR OUR OCEANS!   Last week the UK s North Sea saw a major win for marine life!  On January 30 a judge ruled that the approval of the Rosebank and Jackdaw oil and gas fields was unlawful  stopping these disastrous projects in their tracks. With marine heat waves overfishing and pollution already wreaking havoc on UK seas adding a major oil spill from Rosebank to the mix could have been catastrophic threatening 16 marine protected areas and wildlife from seabirds to seals. This ruling is a historic step toward clean energy and healthier oceans. But the fight isn t over. Oceana_uk is gearing up to challenge even more reckless fossil fuel projects including 31 oil and gas exploration licenses granted in May 2024. The tide is turning. Let s keep pushing for a future where our oceans and our planet come first!  #StopRosebank

Caption: A single drop of water can hold a world of secrets  but we never expected this! Using environmental DNA or eDNA for short our Spring 2024 research expedition with Blancpain1735 and airdrianmv detected more than 11000 unique species in California s Channel Islands including thousands undescribed or potentially unknown to science!   These findings highlight the immense biodiversity of the region as well as how much of our marine ecosystems are still a mystery. And there s still more to come - stay tuned for our next findings!

Caption: Get to meet some of the species that call the Humboldt Archipelago home!  Off the coasts of La Higuera and La Serena in the Coquimbo region and Freirina in the Atacama region Chile lies the Humboldt Archipelago Multiple-Use Coastal Marine Protected Area spanning approximately 5700 square kilometers (2200 square miles).It is one of the 35 biodiversity hotspots in the world and its marine habitat is crucial for the health of the planet. Learn more with the #linkinbio. oceana_chile

Caption: Ivory gulls love life on the ice! With its striking all-white feathers and black legs this hardy seabird is perfectly adapted to life in the icy north. Ivory gulls thrive in some of the most extreme conditions on Earth often found soaring over the Arctic Ocean or perched on floating sea ice.When it comes to food ivory gulls aren t picky they feast on fish crustaceans mollusks and even leftovers from polar bears meals!   But as sea ice disappears due to climate change these birds face an uncertain future. While not currently endangered some ivory gull populations are declining making conservation efforts more important than ever. Learn more about snowy seabirds with our Marine Life Encyclopedia   link in bio. #IvoryGull #Gull #Seabird #MarineLife #AnimalsAtoZ

Caption: It s official: 2024 was the hottest year on record. This means that the past 10 years have been the 10 warmest on record.  And the consequences are devastating for our planet. But there is still hope. We can still avoid the worst effects of climate change and our oceans can be a major part of that solution but we need swift and decisive action NOW. Learn more about how we can prevent climate catastrophe with the #linkinbio.

Caption: After two years the Global Treaty On Plastic Pollution has ended without agreement.Without consensus among the 175 participating countries a new meeting will be scheduled for 2025. But we can t just ignore this plastic problem until then.Oceana remains committed to working towards a legally binding treaty that includes measures for the entire life cycle of plastic and that protects our health and our oceans. We also continue to campaign to stop plastic pollution at the source. Learn more with the #linkinbio. OceanaBrasil

Caption: Making a whale of an entrance!North Atlantic right whale  Nauset  is the first mother to be identified this calving season. She was spotted with her new not-so-little bundle of joy off the Sapelo Island Georgia. This is her fifth known calf with her last born four years ago during the 2021 calving season. Whale-done mama! It s exciting news but these new mother-calf pairs face threats every day from speeding boats which can cause injury or death. Add your name to our petition for stronger protections for the #RightWhaleToSave with the #linkinbio.  : Photograph taken by Clearwater Marine Aquarium Research Institute under NOAA permit 26919

Caption: When a plastic bottle enters the ocean it doesn t stay a bottle forever! Instead plastics break up into smaller and smaller pieces in the ocean. These microplastics can be swallowed by tiny marine animals and when larger animals eat those animals they re unknowingly eating plastic too. Ocean wildlife that eat too many microplastics could suffer from internal injuries delayed growth and even serious behavior changes that threaten the animal s health and long-term survival. Marine life should not have to pay the price for our plastic crisis! Add your name to call for global leaders to protect our oceans and #BreakFreeFromPlastic today. Link in bio.

Caption: We are excited to welcome Dr. Christina Hicks to Oceana s Board of Directors!Dr. Hicks is a world expert on nutrition and ocean health a professor at the University of Lancaster in the UK a Pew Marine Fellow and the recipient of numerous prizes for her research. At Oceana s recent event in New York City she addressed guests about threats facing fishers and families in West Africa and the importance of developing policies that improve fish stocks and benefit local communities.We are glad to have Dr. Hicks  expertise and guidance on our campaigns to save the oceans and feed the world!

Caption: A new Oceana analysis shows nearly 3000 fishing vessels spent months   and sometimes years   at sea without coming to port last year. These long voyages can be a risk indicator of illegal fishing activity or forced labor.  Extensive time at sea keeps vessels away from scrutiny and increases the risk of illicit conduct on the high seas. We cannot have accountability at sea without transparency at sea.    Oceana Campaign Director Dr. Max Valentine Learn more about our analysis with the #linkinbio.  #StopIUUFishing #StopIllegalFishing

Caption: Oceana s new report makes it clear: Coca-Cola is a big contributor to the plastic pollution crisis! By 2030 its plastic use could exceed 9.1 billion pounds per year. But it doesn t have to be this way. Coke already sells billions of drinks in refillable bottles a proven solution that could cut its plastic use below current levels. So why is Coca-Cola backtracking instead of expanding reuse? Let s hold them accountable. Less plastic. More reuse. Healthier oceans.   Learn more about our report at the #linkinbio.

Caption: These tiny Antarctic krill have a huge impact globally!   These little guys are the MVPs of the marine food chain in the Southern Ocean feeding everything from penguins to blue whales!    Although these shrimp-like crustaceans only grow up to 2.5 inches long they are likely the most abundant animal species on Earth in terms of biomass.  Send this to someone who s small but mighty!Learn more about Antarctic Krill and other ocean animals with our Marine Life Encyclopedia. Link in bio.#AntarcticKrill #OceanHeroes #SmallButMight

Caption: Deep-sea discovery alert! For the first time ever a colossal squid has been filmed alive in its natural habitat. Scientists are still learning exactly how big these squids can get with estimates ranging from around 20 feet all the way to 46 feet long although the one filmed here was just a baby. A powerful reminder: there s still so much we don t know about our oceans. Let s protect them before it s too late.   Sighting: schmidtocean

Caption: The government needs to start listening to scientists  because even though it may be politically in the short term inconvenient in the long term it s going to save us from making terrible mistakes.    Dr. Ian L. Jones Biology Professor Memorial UniversityEverything in the ocean is interconnected with everything else. Capelin sit at the center of that web feeding species like humpback whales cod and puffins. However the capelin population in Newfoundland and Labrador is at just 9% of its pre-collapse levels.To protect the health of the ocean marine animals and coastal communities the government needs to rebuild capelin back to health. Learn more and take action at Oceana.ca/ProtectCapelin.

Caption: Things are getting fishy! The Latin American Congress of Marine Science and the Brazilian Congress of Oceanography took place in Brazil last week! Some of the main congresses on marine science in Latin America these conference focus on recent research and innovations in working to achieve healthy oceans. As part of this conference OceanaBrasil held a symposium that brought together international experts to discuss strategies to improve fisheries management and promote environmental conservation. The event  The Perfect Protein: Challenges for the Science and Sustainable Management of Sardines and Other Pelagics in the South Atlantic and Pacific  focused on the importance of sardines anchovies and other fish that play a crucial role in ocean food webs as well as a food source for people around the world. Follow the #linkinbio to learn more about this event and OceanaBrasil s campaign for sustainable fisheries! #COLACMAR2024 #CBO2024 #Oceana #Prote oDosOceanos #Prote naPerfeita

Caption: The Nature Restoration Law has entered into force!It s a truly historic moment as the law sets legally-binding targets for Member States to restore 20% of land areas and 20% of seas by 2030 and all ecosystems in need of restoration by 2050.This follows years of advocacy and campaigning from the #RestoreNature movement to get the Nature Restoration Law across the finish line.

Caption: Saving fish strengthening futures!   In the eastern Philippines lies the island municipality of Daram. With the longest coastline in its province of Samar the island is making waves in the fight against post-harvest fish loss a major challenge for food security and the livelihoods of small-scale fishers.   At a recent Stakeholders  Forum & Field Visit Vice Mayor Lucia Astorga spoke to emphasize the importance of reducing fish loss to ensure more food better nutrition and stronger incomes for coastal communities. Big changes are happening! Daram is implementing a game-changing fish loss reduction plan and catch monitoring system across 58 barangays the smallest local government unit in the Philippines. These innovations which are supported by small-scale fishers government agencies and universities prioritize real solutions for a more sustainable ocean & future.   Oceana s Vice President Atty. Gloria Estenzo Ramos was able to visit and show her support for Daram s inspiring leadership and progress firsthand  because every fish saved means more food more income and a healthier ocean!   #SustainableFishing #FoodSecurity #SaveOurSeas #FishersFirst Oceana_ph

Caption: BREAKING: An oil tanker has collided with a cargo ship off the coast of Britain. Our thoughts are with everyone affected by this tragic event including the crew and first responders. This tragic event has raised serious environmental concerns. While it s too early to fully assess the impact to our oceans one vessel was reported to be carrying of jet fuel. Oceana_UK s Hugotagholm issued the following statement: This incident is a shocking reminder of the ferocious polluting power of oil. We are seeing burning slicks the threat of heavy fuel oil and toxic chemicals leaking in or near not one but two marine protected areas. Places that should be safe havens for wildlife. Southern North Sea and Holderness MPAs protect declining harbour porpoises and rich seafloor habitats both highly sensitive to these toxic spills. Oil is always an accident waiting to happen in our ocean and we are all familiar with its devastating impacts   seabirds slick with oil marine life struggling in tarry tidelines and a toxic legacy that can impact wildlife and coastal communities for years. More oil will always result in more spills.  Oceana staff members are on the ground monitoring the impacts of this toxic oil spill. We will share news about this event as it becomes available.

Caption: In 2021 Chile passed a law law regulating the distribution of single-use and disposable plastics in food establishments which came into play progressively. A central piece of this regulation was set to take effect on August 13 2024 and included among others the prohibition of distribution of any type of disposables for consumption within food establishments including food courts. However earlier in August Congress and the Government agreed to postpone the law by 18 months. However there still are already obligations in effect in Chile!For over a year food vendors have been prohibited from providing Styrofoam plastic cutlery straws or stirrers. Additionally supermarkets and convenience stores must accept and offer returnable bottles!Learn more at the #linkinbio.

Caption: Global sea ice just hit a record low. The amount of ice lost is enough to cover the United States east of the Mississippi River. But this isn t just about numbers sea ice is critical for keeping our planet cool and providing a home for polar bears seals and penguins.    With rising global temperatures the impacts are only getting worse. But there s still time to act. Reducing fossil fuel use and embracing clean energy can help slow ice loss and protect the species that depend on it.

Caption: The fishing sector in Mexico has been neglected over the years despite its importance in bringing healthy and nutritious food to thousands of families. Decision-making must be based on technical and scientific information to ensure that the seas continue to be a source of food and employment.

Caption: We are experiencing hunger   its getting extreme. When you see people there s nothing left of their livelihood. - Virgie Sanares The Philippines Manila Bay is under threat by land reclamation activities. Also called dump-and-fill these projects threaten to fill in areas of Manila Bay and create land so that these areas can be developed. But these activities can drastically change the ecosystem and harm local wildlife and local fishers are paying the price. Oceana_Ph campaigns to stop the illegal dumping and filling of Manila Bay that destroys critical life support systems violates our environmental rights and deprive our artisanal fisherfolk of their livelihood and food security! Learn more with the #linkinbio.#ProtectOurOcean #ProtectOurFisherfolk #MakePollutersPay
